awd_titl_txt: Analysis of Atacama Cosmology Telescope data: cosmology beyond Planck
awd_abstract_narration:
This purpose of this work is to test the standard cosmological model that describes the origins and evolution of the universe. In this model the universe is dominated by as-yet unknown components: dark energy and dark matter, and its large cosmic structures have grown via gravity from initial features imprinted at the start of the universe. This model faces two current issues: the current expansion rate of the universe inferred from two different measurements is in disagreement, and the expected size of cosmic structures is also in some disagreement from different measurements. This work focuses on testing those issues by using new data to make an independent measurement of the expansion rate and the sizes of cosmic structures. The project will have an emphasis on the support and training of junior women in the field, as well as taking steps to recruit women into the field.

This work will use new high resolution, high sensitivity measurements of the Cosmic Microwave Background radiation to make an independent measurement of the expansion rate of the universe, and a refined estimate of the sizes of cosmic structures. The project uses the Atacama Cosmology Telescope, a six-meter NSF-supported telescope in Chile, currently observing the millimeter-wave sky. This work will involve computing key statistical properties of maps of the microwave background radiation to infer the expansion rate of the universe, and combining these data with measurements of the distortions of galaxies from the optical Hyper-Suprime Cam survey, to infer the size of cosmic structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award resulted in new estimates of properties of the universe, obtained by analyzing data from the  Atacama Cosmology Telescope that was collected from 2013-16. This involved making a new measurement of the Cosmic Microwave Background, an image of the universe as it was at 380,000 years old. By measuring the polarization properties of this light at higher sensitivity and resolution then previously accessible to satellite missions, and covering almost half the sky, we were able to refine our estimates of properties of the universe. In particular, our work contributed to a new measurement of the rate of expansion of space, known as the Hubble constant. We found this to be in excellent agreement with a previous measurement from the Planck satellite, convincing the wider astronomical community of the robustness of Cosmic Microwave Background data. While the Hubble constant from ACT agrees with one local estimate of the expansion rate found by looking at the recession speed of galaxies, it is significantly lower than another measurement made using Cepheid variable stars to measure cosmic distances. Understanding whether this difference is a significant problem for the current standard model of cosmology inspired much of our work. Seeking to understand alternative models that might alleviate any difference in expansion rates, we explored ways to change the expansion in the early universe, including neutrinos particles that have unusual interactions, or a new form of vacuum energy that takes effect early in the universe's evolution.

These new results from ACT were made public in 2020; our subsequent work has focused on the higher-sensitivity data collected from ACT during 2017-20, including close attention to the quality of data collected during the daytime, preparing the pipeline and testing the data ready to make state-of-the-art estimates of cosmological quantities, as well as including existing data from the Planck satellite.

Another key project outcome was the production of a new map that indicates the total mass of matter in different directions around us throughout the universe, inferred from the bending of the light measured by ACT due to the gravity of cosmic structures. This was made public in 2020. To use this new map for scientific analysis, our group developed software to combine the information with data from the Hyper Suprime-Cam (HSC) survey, that measures the number and shapes of galaxies, as these also trace the same large cosmic structures. We used these tools to first study how galaxies seen by HSC cluster together in space, developing software that will in the future be used for cosmology analysis of data from the Rubin Observatory.

An important outcome of this project was the provision of data, software and accompanying Jupyter notebooks to the wider community. ACT products and software tools were delivered to the NASA LAMBDA website as the ACT DR4 and DR5 data releases in July 2020 and Feb 2021, with accompanying Zoom webinars attended by hundreds of people, and a follow-up data school for junior scientists in the wider community. Our results were shared with the public as well as the scientific community, with a press release on the Hubble constant results, and participation in radio programs and podcasts.  Reaching a broad audience, Dunkley published a popular science book in 2019: `Our Universe: An Astronomer's Guide', with media engagements and public talks, and a Royal Institution lecture with over 160k online views. 

The award supported a female graduate student and post-doc, preparing them for the next steps in their academic careers. The supported graduate student taught a class at Mercer Community College, and the supported post-docs taught math and physics courses for incarcerated students as part of the Prison Teaching Initiative at Princeton. Group members also created teaching materials for the Simons NSBP Scholars' Program for undergraduate students.
